sources.title: Blazing Justice
sources.description: A cowboy (Bill Cody) captures two rustlers and collects a $5000 reward. Using the money to take a vacation, he winds up getting accused of a murder he didn't commit.

sources.title: Blazing Justice (1936) BILL CODY
sources.description:
Stars: Bill Cody, Gertrude Messinger, Gordon Griffith 
 Director: Albert Herman

 A cowboy captures two rustlers and collects a $5000 reward. Using the money to take a vacation, he winds up getting accused of a murder he didn't commit.

TRIVIA: Born William Joseph Cody on January 5, 1891, in St. Paul, Minnesota, he became a popular cowboy star during the 1920s and 1930s. Cody is often associated with the B-Western genre, where he played the heroic cowboy figure, a staple of American cinema during that period.

metadata.Plot: When the Sheriff is shot, Ray Healy catches two of the bandits, but Max, the third bandit escapes. Later, Max commits another robbery and murder and then switches horses with Ray. After convincing the Sheriff he is innocent, Ray has a plan to lure Max into a trap. It is advertised that the deceased's insurance policy will be paid in cash at his funeral.
metadata.Actors: Bill Cody, Gertrude Messinger, Gordon Griffith
